sub_topic: Finding the maximum or minimum value of a trigonometric function
message_1: A ladder is placed against a wall such that the foot of the ladder is 6 feet away from the wall. The ladder makes an angle of 60 degrees with the ground. What is the minimum length of the ladder in feet required to reach the top of the wall? (Round your answer to two decimal places)
message_2:
To find the minimum length of the ladder, we can use the trigonometric function sine. The sine of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the hypotenuse (the ladder in this case).

sin(60째) = opposite side (height of the wall) / hypotenuse (length of the ladder)

We are given that the foot of the ladder is 6 feet away from the wall, which is the adjacent side in the right triangle. We can use the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of the wall.

a^2 + b^2 = c^2
where a is the adjacent side (6 feet), b is the opposite side (height of the wall), and c is the hypotenuse (length of the ladder).

We can also use the trigonometric function cosine to find the height of the wall. The cosine of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side adjacent to the angle to the length of the hypotenuse.

cos(60째) = adjacent side (6 feet) / hypotenuse (length of the ladder)

cos(60째) = 0.5 (since cos(60째) = 1/2)

0.5 = 6 / length of the ladder

Now, we can solve for the length of the ladder:

length of the ladder = 6 / 0.5
length of the ladder = 12 feet

So, the minimum length of the ladder required to reach the top of the wall is 12 feet.
